a9869efc19b45caf6dfd57855aecc10a (13:01): +anyone knows whats the command to : cp a folder to a directory and overwrite ervtyuhing in the dir?>
e75308f7c2ef4fdf985e0e26363b080b (13:03): +mRCUTEO, You want to copy a folder to the home directory overwriting?
e75308f7c2ef4fdf985e0e26363b080b (13:03): +mRCUTEO, cp source ~/ -Rf
e75308f7c2ef4fdf985e0e26363b080b (13:03): +mRCUTEO, or is it more complicated than that?
a9869efc19b45caf6dfd57855aecc10a (13:03): +chmac that`ll overwrite evrything ?
68c1841b03f8e4107b9be6924ca702db (13:03): +make an archive. Use tar. Sounds like a better idea.
a9869efc19b45caf6dfd57855aecc10a (13:04): +okie Anvil
e75308f7c2ef4fdf985e0e26363b080b (13:04): +mRCUTEO, You want to delete everything that's there, or just overwrite? I believe -f will overwrite yes...
a9869efc19b45caf6dfd57855aecc10a (13:04): +overwrite
a9869efc19b45caf6dfd57855aecc10a (13:04): +not delete evrything
e75308f7c2ef4fdf985e0e26363b080b (13:04): +mRCUTEO, yeah, -f should do it, check out man cp
e75308f7c2ef4fdf985e0e26363b080b (13:05): +-r or -R will copy directories recursively (ie, copy all of them)
e75308f7c2ef4fdf985e0e26363b080b (13:05): +~/ is a shortcut to the current user's home directory
68c1841b03f8e4107b9be6924ca702db (13:05): +"without keeping permissions / attributes"
68c1841b03f8e4107b9be6924ca702db (13:05): +you'd better read the man cp for more informations.
68c1841b03f8e4107b9be6924ca702db (13:06): +-f is not needed to overwrite.
a9869efc19b45caf6dfd57855aecc10a (13:06): +chmac: is this correct : cp myfolder myOLDfolder -Rf >
a9869efc19b45caf6dfd57855aecc10a (13:06): +chmac: is this correct : cp myfolder myOLDfolder -Rf ?
68c1841b03f8e4107b9be6924ca702db (13:06): +dont use that damn -f
e75308f7c2ef4fdf985e0e26363b080b (13:07): +mRCUTEO, lol, I'm guessing -f is not recommended!
a9869efc19b45caf6dfd57855aecc10a (13:07): +why not ?
e75308f7c2ef4fdf985e0e26363b080b (13:07): +beats me, but I've no doubt Anvil will shed some light upon it...
68c1841b03f8e4107b9be6924ca702db (13:07): +mRCUTEO : why do you need it ?
a9869efc19b45caf6dfd57855aecc10a (13:08): +okie heres my sit
a9869efc19b45caf6dfd57855aecc10a (13:08): +i have 2 folder
68c1841b03f8e4107b9be6924ca702db (13:08): +you dont know what you're doing. Do use a -f
a9869efc19b45caf6dfd57855aecc10a (13:08): +one is old and one is new
e75308f7c2ef4fdf985e0e26363b080b (13:08): +mRCUTEO, Ok, try it without the f, just "cp olddir newdir -r"
68c1841b03f8e4107b9be6924ca702db (13:08): +That's not my point
68c1841b03f8e4107b9be6924ca702db (13:08): +I know what you're trying to do
68c1841b03f8e4107b9be6924ca702db (13:08): +why ho why do you think you need a -f ?

e75308f7c2ef4fdf985e0e26363b080b (13:08): +mRCUTEO, that'll copy the directories with all their contents, if it prompts you to overwrite a zillion times, hit CTRL-C and then use -f or something else that'll stop the prompts
426d23ac558f147976698cb2d5d19c48 (13:09): +is there a nice list of all FC5 repos somewhere?

a9869efc19b45caf6dfd57855aecc10a (13:09): +chmac: will cp olddir newdir -r <--- will this copy the contents of the new folder to the old forlder without deleteting old folder content which is different?
e75308f7c2ef4fdf985e0e26363b080b (13:09): +yes, copy old to new, no deletion of old
a9869efc19b45caf6dfd57855aecc10a (13:10): +chmac : okie
a9869efc19b45caf6dfd57855aecc10a (13:10): +okie ill try that
a9869efc19b45caf6dfd57855aecc10a (13:13): +chmac: is : cp new old -rf okie?
e75308f7c2ef4fdf985e0e26363b080b (13:14): +mRCUTEO, Is -r asking you to confirm you want to overwrite every time?
68c1841b03f8e4107b9be6924ca702db (13:14): +-r doesnt ask anything
68c1841b03f8e4107b9be6924ca702db (13:14): +If your cp is aliased to cp -i then it will by default.
e75308f7c2ef4fdf985e0e26363b080b (13:14): +Anvil, Is non-interactive the default?
a9869efc19b45caf6dfd57855aecc10a (13:14): +Anvil: okie
a9869efc19b45caf6dfd57855aecc10a (13:15): +thanks to both of you..
e75308f7c2ef4fdf985e0e26363b080b (13:15): +Anvil, Damn, I didn't realise that, is there an option to overwrite the -i
68c1841b03f8e4107b9be6924ca702db (13:16): +chmac : why dont you just unalias cp ? -_-
e75308f7c2ef4fdf985e0e26363b080b (13:16): +Anvil, I could, but I figure it's probably not a bad idea to have interactive as the default
e75308f7c2ef4fdf985e0e26363b080b (13:16): +Anvil, if I can override it manually

aff0f0089eb5e7489e6f10b7b004ad7c (14:21): +I have not found BETTER ftp client for GUI than gftp. It has been a part core of Linux GUI bin utils under Linux since year 2000 or so - stable and well functioning under all most popular Linux GUI desktop managers, but that's only my opinion!  I also use konqueror as my ftp client that works great as well :)
